tn.ref: your prayer and your request
tn.text: The words "prayer" and "request" mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh recognized that Solomon's request was sincere. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:08:27|8:28]]. AT: "your request" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: to put my name there forever
tn.text: The name is a metonym for the person. AT: "to dwell there and to claim possession of it forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: My eyes and my heart will be there
tn.text: The eyes and heart are synecdoche for the whole person. AT: "I will protect and care for it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: if you walk before me as David your father walked
tn.text: The way a person lives is spoken of as if that person were walking on a path. AT: "if you live the way I want you to live, just as David your father did" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: in integrity of heart and in uprightness
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize how righteous David was. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: the throne of your kingdom
tn.text: Here "throne" refers to his reign. AT: "your dynasty" or "your reign" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: will never fail to be on the throne of Israel
tn.text: The action of ruling a kingdom is spoken of as if it were a person sitting on a throne. This can be expressed positively. AT: "will always rule over Israel" (See:  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: my commandments and my statutes
tn.text: Here the words "commandments" and "statutes" mean basically the same thing and emphasize all that Yahweh has commanded. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: worship other gods and bow down to them
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: set apart to my name
tn.text: Here the word "name" is a metonym for the person who possesses something. AT: "set apart for myself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I will cast it out of my sight
tn.text: The abstract noun "sight" can be expressed with the verb "see." Looking at something is a metaphor for protecting it. AT: "I will put it where I no longer have to see it" or "I will get rid of it so I no longer have to protect it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: This temple will become a heap of ruins
tn.text: "This temple will be destroyed and its remains will be piled into a high mound"

tn.ref: will be shocked and will hiss
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "will express amazement and make a sound of disrespect" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: bowed down to them and worshiped them
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing. The phrase "bowed down to them" describes the posture that people used in worship. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: It came about
tn.text: This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way of doing this, you could consider using it here.

tn.ref: at the end of twenty years
tn.text: "after 20 years"

tn.ref: Solomon had finished building
tn.text: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: What cities are these which you have given me, my brother?
tn.text: Hiram is rebuking Solomon. AT: "These cities that you have given me are good for nothing." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: which they are still called today
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "and people still call them that today" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: 120 talents of gold
tn.text: A talent is a unit of weight equal to about 34 kilograms. AT: "about 4,000 kilograms of gold." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])

tn.ref: the reason for the requirement to work which King Solomon imposed
tn.text: "the reason that King Solomon required men to work"

tn.ref: to build the Millo
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "to build the terrace system" or 2) "to build the landfill" (UDB).

tn.ref: Pharaoh king of Egypt had gone up
tn.text: The person is a metonym for the army he commands. AT: "The army of Pharaoh, king of Egypt, had gone up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: So Solomon rebuilt Gezer
tn.text: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Solomon made no forced laborers of the people of Israel
tn.text: "Solomon did not force the people of Israel to labor"

tn.ref: 550 of them
tn.text: "five hundred and fifty of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: built the Millo
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "built the terrace system" or 2) "built the landfill" (UDB). See how you translated "the Millo" in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:09:15|9:15]].

tn.ref: altar that was before Yahweh
tn.text: Translate this phrase as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:08:64|8:64]].

tn.ref: So he completed the temple
tn.text: Solomon is a metonym for the workers he hired to do the work. AT: "So his workers completed the temple" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: King Solomon built
tn.text: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: a fleet of ships
tn.text: "a large group of ships"

tn.ref: 420 talents of gold
tn.text: A talent is a unit of weight equal to about 34 kilograms. AT: "about 14,000 kilograms of gold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])
